content:
• Monday, January 7, 2019
  • DPLO

    UNP, NE & CPE among notable after hour movers

    • Gainers: DPLO +11.7%. UNP +6.7%. CMC +5.8%. MED +4.4%. CWEN +4.2%.
    • Losers: NE -8.7%. GTT -8.1%. HPR -7.9%. WLH -7.4%. CPE -7.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM | 10 Comments
  • VIVO

    Meridian Bioscience -1.7% on preliminary Q1 revenues

    • Meridian Bioscience (NASDAQ:VIVO) has dipped 1.7% in postmarket trading after announcing disappointing preliminary results for first-quarter revenues.
    • The company sees revenues at $51M-$51.5M, compared with a year-ago $52.3M and consensus for $53.7M.
    • Revenues for Life Science are expected to be in line with the previous year, but the Diagnostics segment is weaker, Meridian notes.
    • "Demand in the first quarter was softer than expected in both of our business segments," says CEO Jack Kenny. "In Diagnostics, we experienced weakness in major molecular product lines. In Life Science, bulk order shipments, which are historically prone to quarterly swings, were also weaker than planned, particularly for immunoassay products and in China."
    • The company will hold its earnings call Jan. 24. It presents at the J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference on Thursday at 1:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:30 PM
  • UNP

    Union Pacific +6.7% after bringing Vena out of retirement as COO

    • Union Pacific (NYSE:UNP) has risen 6.7% in postmarket trading on heavy volume after naming Jim Vena its chief operating officer, effective Jan. 14.
    • The 60-year-old Vena -- a former protege of Hunter Harrison at Canadian National (NYSEARCA:CN) -- had retired in 2016 after 40 years with that railway.
    • At CN, he led the best operating ratio in North American rail and achieved the best safety incident ratio in company history.
    • He'll report to Union Pacific Chairman/President/CEO Lance Fritz.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM | 18 Comments
  • STX

    Seagate unveils new storage solutions

    • Seagate (NASDAQ:STX) announces its newest lineup of storage solutions at #CES19:
    • The LaCie line gains the Mobile Drive (max 5TB) and Mobile SSD with speeds of up to 540MB/s and max 2TB capacity. Both are available this month.
    • The Backup Plus family of portable external drives gets the Backup Plus Ultra Touch (1TB and 2TB capacities), Backup Plus Slim (1TB and 2TB), and Backup Plus Portable (4TB and 5TB). The Ultra Touch will become available next month and the others arrive in March. 
    • For PC gamers, STX has the FireCuda 510 M.2 PCIe NVMe SSD with its ultra-small M.2 2280 form factor, 4K video processing, and high IOPS. There's also the BarraCuda 510 M.2 PCIe NVMe SSD for faster applications. The products will be available sometime this spring. 
    • For enterprises, Seagate says the IronWolf 110 SATA SSD is the first purpose-built NAS SSD. IronWolf offers capacities of up to 3.84TB, includes Durawrite tech for faster read/write , and has up to 7000 TBW.  IronWolf 110 is available this month. 
    • STX shares are up 1.3% aftermarket to $39.65.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM | 13 Comments
  • GRUB

    ANGI +1.3%, RDFN -0.5% after Needham coverage starts

    • ANGI Homeservices is up 1.3% after hours following an update on service providers where Needham has initiated the company at Buy.
    • The firm has a price target of $23, implying 49.2% upside.
    • It's Neutral in starts on other providers: The firm has launched coverage on GrubHub (NYSE:GRUB) at Hold and Yelp (NYSE:YELP) at Hold. GrubHub rose 5.3% during the regular session.
    • In online real estate services, Needham has started Zillow (Z, ZG) at Hold and Redfin (NASDAQ:RDFN) at Underperform. RDFN is off 0.5% in postmarket action.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM | 3 Comments
  • NLY

    Annaly Capital -2.7% on plans for 75M-share public offering

    • Annaly Capital Management (NYSE:NLY) sinks 2.7% in after-hours trading after announcing plans to sell 75M shares of common stock in a public offering.
    • Greenshoe option for an additional 11.25M shares.
    • Net proceeds for acquiring targeted assets under its capital allocation policy; also for general corporate purposes, which may included paying down obligations and other working capital items.
    • Previously: Annaly Capital Management lower 2.8% on announcing pricing of common stock (Sept. 12, 2018)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM | 48 Comments
  • LEU

    Centrus Energy +21% on anticipated $115M Energy Department contract

    • Centrus Energy (LEU +21.5%) surged in today's trade after the U.S. Energy Department announced plans to spend $115M on a project to help develop advanced fuels for next-generation reactors.
    • DoE officials say they plan to award the contract to Centrus's American Centrifuge Operating unit unless rival companies can make a compelling case by Jan. 22.
    • Russia is the only country capable of producing the higher-enriched uranium the DoE’s new program would produce; without it, the U.S. risks being left out of the global industry’s next stage, says Deputy Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM
  • MNK

    Mallinckrodt to spin out generics business in H2; shares up 6%

    • Mallinckrodt (MNK +5.5%) CEO Mark Trudeau says his company expects to spin out its generic business in H2 or earlier, adding that he intends to raise new debt for the standalone company consistent with a 3.5x - 4.0x leverage ratio.
    • In the meantime, management's priority will be to reduce debt on the enterprise's balance sheet.
    • Most of the manufacturing assets will go with the spin-out.
    • Detailed 2019 guidance will be released with Q4 results in late February.
    • Source: Bloomberg
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 3 Comments
  • GE

    GE +6% for sixth straight gain; talk of jet leasing unit deal prompts upgrade

    • General Electric (GE +6%) pushes forward to its sixth straight gains and its best level in two months on reports that Apollo Global will bid to buy all or part of GE Capital Aviation Services, despite some analyst skepticism.
    • CFRA analyst Jim Corridore upgrades GE to Buy from Hold and raises his price target to $11, saying "with GE preparing to spin off healthcare and sell off its share in Baker Hughes, we think this news could provide a path to fix GE's highly leveraged balance sheet."
    • Meanwhile, J.P. Morgan bear Stephen Tusa believes a sale would not prove the "silver bullet" to leverage issues that bulls expect, but says the time likely is approaching where GE will provide something "more tangible, perhaps shrinking the balance sheet," that will make the company easier to value.
    • However, related dilution, combined with a full "cleanse" of the accounting structure, should result in a "substantially lower run rate fundamental anchor than many appreciate," Tusa says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM | 37 Comments
  • VIA

    Fox: CBS CEO search snags as candidates drop out

    • CBS (CBS +1.3%) is losing some potential CEO candidates as they choose to drop out, though that's not slowing the company's timetable, Fox Business says.
    • The board still looks to choose a permanent successor to ex-CEO Les Moonves by the end of this quarter, Charlie Gasparino is saying, though there's "somewhat of a snag" as it's having a difficult time finding someone who both wants the job and is qualified.
    • And that CEO hiring could be complicated by parallel moves to find a merger partner (discussions that always include Viacom (VIA +6.3%, VIAB +4.9%)), Fox says.
    • Even if someone becomes the CEO this quarter, "he may not be CEO for very long," Gasparino says.
    • Previously: Report: CBS seeking CEO who could also run Viacom (Jan. 07 2019)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM | 2 Comments
  • TEVA

    Teva outlook on stable prices buoys generics

    • Generic drug makers are in the green after Teva Pharmaceutical Industries (TEVA +1.9%) chief Kåre Schultz stated that he sees stable prices this year, a welcome view considering the downward pressure last year. He made the comment during his presentation at the JP Morgan Healthcare Conference.
    • Selected tickers: (ACET +4.8%)(ACRS +2.2%)(AKRX +6.8%)(AMRX +0.2%)(ANIP +3.2%)(BHC +5.6%)(CHRS +17.5%)(ENDP +10%)(LCI +21.3%)(MNK +5.7%)(MYL +3.5%)(PRGO +3.9%)(TLGT +7%)
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 3:51 PM | 11 Comments
  • XNCR

    Xencor regains rights to bispecific antibody from Novartis; shares up 4%

    • Xencor (XNCR +3.9%) will regain the ex-U.S. rights to XmAB13676, a CD20 x CD3 bispecific antibody, from Novartis (NVS -1.2%) effective June 20. NVS backed away from the candidate due to new strategic priorities.
    • Preliminary data from a Phase 1 study in patients with B-cell cancers should be available this year.
    • The companies will continue to collaborate on developing XmAb14045. It owns U.S. rights while NVS owns ex-U.S. rights.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:43 PM | 3 Comments
  • PTCT

    PTC Therapeutics 2019 guidance fails to lift shares, down 2%

    • PTC Therapeutics (PTCT -1.9%) is down on 25% higher volume following its release of 2019 guidance.
    • Product revenues: $285M - 305M; R&D and SG&A expenses: $395M - 405M.
    • 2018 guidance: Translarna sales: ~$171M; Emflaza sales: ~$91M; cash and equivalents at year-end: ~$227M.
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 3:37 PM
  • NTGR

    NetGear updates Orbi with Wi-Fi 6

    • NetGear (NTGR +2%) announces the upcoming expansion of its Orbi Mesh Wi-Fi System to include the Wi-Fi 6-enabled Orbi Whole Home Wi-Fi System.
    • The Mesh Wi-Fi System will gain 1024 QAM with a 4x4 Wi-Fi 6 backhaul, increasing the speeds, coverage and capacity.
    • Orbi with Wi-Fi 6 will launch in the second half of 2019.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:24 PM

  • Stocks slip from session highs in late trading

    • U.S. stocks ease off from session highs. The S&P, earlier up as much as 1.2%, pares down to a 0.9% increase.
    • Nasdaq +1.4% and Dow +0.6%.
    • By sector, services (+1.8%) and conglomerates (+1.3%) lead, with utilities (-0.6%) and consumer goods (+0.4%) lagging.
    • Oil increases 1.5% to $48.66/bbl and gold +0.3% to $1,289.10/ounce.
    • 10-year Treasury yield rises 2 basis points to 2.69%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:22 PM | 5 Comments
  • OCUL

    Ocular Therapeutix teams up with Purdue Pharma to develop new pain meds

    • Ocular Therapeutix (OCUL -2.8%) initiates research with Purdue Pharma L.P. to determine the compatibility of the latter's non-opioid molecules with its bioresorbable hydrogel-based technology with the ultimate goal of developing new pain medications.
    • OCUL will initiate formulation testing aimed at advancing candidates to a point where efficacy can be assessed.
    • Financial terms are not disclosed.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:20 PM | 7 Comments
  • TSLA

    Tesla starts taking Model 3 orders in China

    • Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) says customers in China can now order a Model 3 vehicle off the company's website.
    • The announcement follows the groundbreaking earlier today of the Gigfactory in Shanghai.
    • Last week, Tesla said it expected to start making Model 3 deliveries in the region during March.
    • Shares of Tesla are up 5.25% to $334.38 vs. a 52-week trading range of $244.59 to $387.46.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:20 PM | 131 Comments
  • EHC

    Encompass Health up 2% on updated 2018 guidance and 2019 outlook

    • Encompass Health (EHC +1.9%) is up on modestly higher volume after updating its 2018 guidance and providing its outlook for this year.
    • 2018: Revenues: $4,260M - 4,280M from $4,520M - 4,300M; non-GAAP EBITDA: $890M - 895M from $880M - 890M; non-GAAP EPS: $3.62 - 3.66 from $3.55 3.63.
    • 2019: Revenues: $4,500M - 4,600; non-GAAP EBITDA: $925M - 945M; non-GAAP EPS: $3.71 - 3.85.
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 3:14 PM
  • MAT

    Mattel extends bounce off 52-week low

    • Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) is up another 7.49% after a strong move on Friday when shares bounced from a 52-week low.
    • Over the weekend, the company announced a new worldwide licensing agreement with a popular South Korean boy band.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:11 PM
  • VRAY

    ViewRay files for $250M mixed shelf offering

    • ViewRay (VRAY +7.5%) has filed a prospectus for a $250M mixed shelf offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:04 PM

  • Semis outperform ahead of CES

    • The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index gains 2.2% compared to the tech sector (NYSEARCA:XLK) +0.7% ahead of CES 2019 with Nvidia +5.7% and AMD +7.6% leading the way after the former's presentation yesterday that included a new gaming chip.
    • AMD chief Lisa Su will present a keynote address on Wednesday at 9 AM PT.
    • Related semiconductor ETFs: SOXL, SOXX, SMH, USD, PSI, XSD, SOXS, SSG, FTXL, XTH
     
     
     
     
    | 3:01 PM | 1 Comment
  • STML

    Stemline files Elzonris marketing application Europe for BPDCN; shares up 2%

    • Stemline Therapeutics (STML +2.1%) has filed a marketing application in Europe seeking approval for ELZONRIS (tagraxofusp) for blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm (BPDCN), a rare type of blood cancer. The CD123-directed cytotoxin has accelerated view status.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:01 PM
  • LXFT

    PLUG, MAXR & LXFT among tech movers

    • Gainers: Luxoft Holding (NYSE:LXFT) +82%. CLPS Incorporation (NASDAQ:CLPS) +33%. Plug Power (NASDAQ:PLUG) +14%. SilverSun Technologies (NASDAQ:SSNT) +11%. i3 Verticals (NASDAQ:IIIV) +11%.
    • Losers: Maxar Technologies (NYSE:MAXR) -31%. FTE Networks (NYSEMKT:FTNW) -14%. Gridsum Holding (NASDAQ:GSUM) -13%. Uxin Limited (NASDAQ:UXIN) -9%. Boxlight Corporation (NASDAQ:BOXL) -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:01 PM
  • SBGL

    Sibanye sees earnings hit as strike at gold mines drags on

    • Sibanye-Stillwater (SBGL -4.8%) says the strike at its South African gold mines since November may hurt earnings and revenues, as inconsistent production at three mines has limited operations.
    • The strike will not force a restructuring of the affected mines, but there could be a review if the impact is severe, SBGL says.
    • Talks between the company and the AMCU union have made no progress so far.
    • SBGL cannot afford a prolonged production hiatus at its gold operations even though a rally in palladium has provided some cushion, says Vunani Securities analyst Hurbey Geldenhuys.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:51 PM | 24 Comments
  • SRPT

    Sarepta advancing DMD pipeline; shares down 9% on soft Exondys 51 Q4 sales

    • At JPM19, Sarepta Therapeutics (SRPT -9%) updated investors on its DMD line-up. Highlights:
    • SRP-4045 (casimersen): 45 biopsies to be run this quarter. If positive, a U.S. marketing application will be filed this year with the expectation of early 2020 approval.
    • Micro-Dystrophin gene therapy: Dosing in children began last month. Buildout of commercial supply in process. Pivotal study to start this year. Commercial supply to support dosing in H2.
    • Dosing underway in Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy. Biopsy data should be available this quarter.
    • MPS: Dosing to start this quarter in pivotal study run by Lysogene.
    • Source: Tweet from attendee @MauriceOnTW
    • Previously: Sarepta down 5% on preliminary Exondys 51 sales (Jan. 7)
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM | 6 Comments
  • T

    BTIG: AT&T's 'fake' 5G still provides chance to pass Verizon

    • AT&T (T +2.6%) has a real chance to surpass Verizon (VZ +0.9%) in network dominance thanks to deploying 60 MHz of faster spectrum this year, BTIG's Walt Piecyk says.
    • The two telecom giants are locked in an arms race to claim various "firsts" in the road to 5G -- where standards are still not final -- and AT&T is marketing the new spectrum as "5Ge," a move that's drawn criticism from the industry including claims of "fake 5G."
    • The spectrum may not be "true" 5G, but "the bigger picture is that AT&T's network is getting a big lift," Piecyk says.
    • "The tech media can scold AT&T for using 5Ge, but if implemented properly, the AT&T customer should notice a material improvement in performance when the 5Ge tag appears on their phone," Piecyk writes.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM | 85 Comments
  • VTL

    Vital Therapies to acquire Immunic AG in all-stock deal

    • Vital Therapies (VTL -6.8%) has agreed to acquire all outstanding shares of Planegg-Martinsried, Germany-based Immunic AG, a developer of therapies for chronic inflammatory and autoimmune diseases.
    • The combined company, 11% owned by VTL shareholders and 89% owned by Immunic shareholders, will do business as Immunic and will trade on the Nasdaq global market. Prior to closing, VTL management will seek shareholder approval for a reverse stock split.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:14 PM | 5 Comments
  • AMZN

    Amazon Key comes to Ring, garages, businesses

    • Amazon's (AMZN +2.9%) keyless parcel delivery service expands its offering for Prime customers.
    • Key for Garage works with CGI's myQ-connected garage door opener to allow remote garage monitoring and keyless deliveries. The service will launch in Q2.
    • Key for Business is a smart fob for delivery drivers taking packages to commercial and multi-unit residential properties. Building owners and managers can give the drivers controlled access for the deliveries. Key for Business is now available.
    • The Schlage Encode Smart WiFi Deadbolt is the first WiFi-enabled smart lock for Key and aimed at renters or others who don't want to use a hub or hardware for the Key experience. The deadbolt costs $249.99 (or $299.99 bundled with a Cloud Cam) and is available now for pre-order with shipments starting March 5.
    • Ring customers will be able to unlock Key-compatible smart locks from within the Ring app. The feature will launch in Q1.
    • #CES19
    • Previously: Ring launches smart peephole, security lights (Jan. 7)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:09 PM | 5 Comments
  • MRTX

    Mirati up 7% on clinical collaboration with BMY in lung cancer

    • Mirati Therapeutics (MRTX +6.7%) is up on below-average volume on the heels of its clinical collaboration with Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY +3.5%) evaluating the combination of sitravatinib and Opdivo (nivolumab) for the second-line treatment of patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have progressed after platinum-based chemo and a checkpoint inhibitor.
    • A Phase 3 study should launch in H1. Mirati will conduct the trial while BMY will supply product.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:00 PM | 2 Comments
  • QEP

    QEP Resources and ION Geophysical among Energy/Materials gainers; Hi-Crush Partners Sanchez Midstream Partners among losers

    • Gainers: QEP Resources (NYSE:QEP) +42%. ION Geophysical (NYSE:IO) +24%. Centrus Energy (NYSEMKT:LEU) +23%. Ferroglobe (NASDAQ:GSM) +22%. Calumet Specialty Products Partners (NASDAQ:CLMT) +19%.
    • Losers: Hi-Crush Partners (NYSE:HCLP) -15%. Sanchez Midstream Partners (NYSEMKT:SNMP) -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:59 PM
  • PBR

    Petrobras +4% as Brazil government said to award $14B for transfer of rights

    • Petrobras (PBR +3.9%) pops after Brazilian newspaper Valor Economico reported the government will pay $14B to the company to settle a dispute about the offshore transfer of rights area.
    • The newspaper, which did not say how it obtained the information in its report, said the settlement has been discussed with new Pres. Bolsonaro’s transition team.
    • The $14B is a "good number," says Adeodato Volpi Netto, head of capital markets at Eleven Financial Research, and would "enable the materialization of different scenarios that depended on this definition [of the amount the company will receive]. Many of the company’s investment programs and partnerships depended on an understanding of its ability to work on leverage, cash management."
    • The dispute over the oil in question and the price of it dates back to 2010, when the Brazilian government granted PBR the right to extract 5B barrels of oil and gas in the offshore Santos Basin.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:59 PM
  • MYGN

    Myriad Genetics down 11% on bearish reports

    • Myriad Genetics (MYGN -11.4%) is under pressure on almost 60% higher volume on the heels of two bearish reports from the Southern Investigative Reporting Foundation (SIRF).
    • The first questions the usefulness of its GeneSight in major depressive disorder and management's over-selling of its benefits. The second states that its revenues have been inflated is a loophole in Medicare reimbursement.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM | 12 Comments
  • ICE

    Exchange stocks slide after report of new competitor

    • NYSE-owner Intercontinental Exchange (ICE -1.7%), Cboe Global Markets (CBOE -0.1%), and Nasdaq (NDAQ -2.4%) slump after the Wall Street Journal reports that a group of nine financial firms are planning to start their own low-cost stock exchange.
    • Initial investors of the Members Exchange, or MEMX, include Morgan Stanley (MS +1.7%), Fidelity Investments, Citadel Securities, Bank of America (BAC +0.6%) Merrill Lynch, UBS (UBS +1.4%), Virtu Financial (VIRT -0.3%), Charles Schwab (SCHW +1.4%), E*Trade Financial (ETFC +1.8%), and TD Ameritrade (AMTD +0.9%).
    • Previously: Wall Street firms to form stock exchange to rival NYSE, Nasdaq: WSJ (Jan. 7)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:37 PM | 6 Comments
  • RDUS

    Radius Health sees U.S. sales as high as $175M this year; shares up 3%

    • Radius Health (RDUS +3.2%) reports that its has surpassed 2018 guidance with TYMLOS (abaloparatide) generating more than $98M in sales. A 5.9% price hike went into effect on January 1.
    • Quick assets totaled more than $220M at year-end.
    • 2019 outlook: TYMLOS sales of $155M - 175M (unchanged).
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 1:24 PM | 1 Comment
  • TRN

    Trinity Industries guardrail case turned away by U.S. Supreme Court

    • Trinity Industries (TRN +2.6%) is higher after the U.S. Supreme Court denies a whistleblower's request to revive a $663M judgment against the company in a lawsuit accusing TRN of failing to tell the U.S. government about changes made to a guardrail system that raised safety concerns.
    • The Court thus leaves in place a 2017 decision by the Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturning a 2014 verdict by a federal jury in Texas that found TRN had defrauded the government.
    • TRN says the ruling further confirms its long-standing belief that it did not violate the False Claims Act regarding the ET Plus highway end terminal system.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:21 PM | 1 Comment
  • TGT

    Retail sector breaks higher

    • Retail heavyweights Target (TGT +5%), Walmart (WMT +1.8%) and Macy's (M +3.2%) are outperforming broad market averages. A resumption of U.S.-China trade talks and more positive read-through on Friday's strong jobs report may be helping to bring some buyers back into the sector.
    • Notable gainers include Ascena Retail (ASNA +11.7%), Stein Mart (SMRT +5.6%), Boot Barn (BOOT +8.7%), Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF +7.5%), The Children's Place (PLCE +6.7%), Gap (GPS +6.2%), Express (EXPR +5.3%), Ross Stores (ROST +5.3%), J. Jill (JILL +4%), L Brands (LB +6.9%), Ollie's Bargain Outlet Holdings (OLLI +7.5%), Dollar Tree (DLTR +6.1%), Burlington Stores (BURL +3.3%), Stitch Fix (SFIX +9%), Farfetch (FTCH +6.2%) and The Container Store (TCS +5.7%).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM | 24 Comments
  • BLUE

    Bluebird bio up 8% on CAR-T development deal with Inhibrx

    • Bluebird bio (BLUE +7.6%) is up on below-average volume on the heels of its announced license agreement with privately held Inhibrx aimed at researching, developing and commercializing CAR-T therapies leveraging the latter's single domain antibody platform.
    • Under the terms of the partnership, BLUE will own exclusive global rights to certain unnamed CAR-T candidates for the potential treatment of a range of cancers. Inhibrx received $7M upfront and will be eligible to receive milestones and tiered royalties on net sales.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:13 PM | 2 Comments
  • JAGX

    Jaguar Health up 13.4% on 4Q18 commercial sales updates

    • Jaguar Health (JAGX +13.4%) announces commercial sales updates for 4Q18.
    • Mytesi gross sales for Q4 to be ~$2.18M, and Mytesi net sales to be ~$1.55M, representing growth of 37% Q/Q and 40% Q/Q. This exceeds 4Q17 gross and net sales by ~136% and ~123%.
    • FY18 gross sales are expected to be ~$5.726M, and Mytesi net sales are expected to be ~$4M.
    • The Company expects to file its Form 10-K in mid-February 2019.
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 1:07 PM
  • ALNY

    Alnylam up 9% on Q4 Onpattro sales

    • Alnylam Pharmaceuticals (ALNY +9.3%) is up on below-average volume on the heels of its announcement of preliminary Q4 2018 results.
    • ONPATTRO (patisiran) sales were $11M - 12M. Over 200 patients in the U.S. and Europe are receiving commercial treatment.
    • Quick assets totaled ~$1.1B at year-end. Complete 2019 guidance will be released next month when it reports Q4 and 2018 full-year results.
    • #JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 1:02 PM
  • LGIH

    LGI Homes leads financial gainers; Maiden Holdings and EZCORP among losers

    • Gainers: LGI Homes (NASDAQ:LGIH) +12%. EverQuote (NASDAQ:EVER) +8%. Monroe Capital (NASDAQ:MRCC) +8%. Elevate Credit (NYSE:ELVT) +7%.
    • Losers: EZCORP (NASDAQ:EZPW) -7%. Maiden Holdings (NASDAQ:MHLD) -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM | 1 Comment
  • SEDG

    SolarEdge to buy Italian e-mobility firm SMRE for $77M

    • SolarEdge Technologies (SEDG -2.9%) agrees to acquire a 51% stake in Italian electric vehicle power train manufacturer SMRE for $77M in cash and shares.
    • Under Italian takeover rules, the Israeli company will be obligated to make an offer for the remaining 49% of SMRE, which is listed on Italy's AIM stock exchange.
    • SEDG expects the initial acquisition to reduce its cash balance by $39M, which will be reflected in Q1 cash flow and involve the issuance of ~1.1M common shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM | 10 Comments
  • TBPH

    Theravance up 4% on downsizing, focus on late-stage programs

    • Theravance Biopharma (TBPH +3.7%) is up on below-average volume on the heels of its announced downsizing aimed at sharpening its strategic focus on selected late-stage programs. The company plans to cut ~50 positions, mostly in early research and infrastructure support for VIBATIV (telavancin), recently sold to Cumberland Pharmaceuticals.
    • $JPM19
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM
  • AXSM

    Healthcare dominate midday movers

    • Amazon's (AMZN +3.1%) Ring announces 13 new products today ahead of #CES19.

    • Security products: The Smoke & CO Listener ($35), First Alert Z-Wave Smoke / CO Alarm ($40), and Flood & Freeze Sensor ($35) can detect threats and notify you through the Ring app. The Dome Siren will ring/flash to indicate security issues while you're home.

  • RDC

    Rowan shareholder Canyon Capital to vote against Ensco deal

    • Rowan (RDC +7.2%) shareholder Canyon Capital says it plans to vote against the company's proposed merger with Ensco (ESV +6.3%), saying the all-stock deal undervalues RDC and exposes the company's shareholders to operational and financial risks.
    • RDC investors would be better served if the company ran a competitive process that resulted in a sale at a higher price or a breakup and sale in parts, according to Canyon, which owns a 6.3% stake in the company.
    • Canyon says RDC has better assets and a stronger balance sheet than the purchase price reflects, and believes the merger would saddle the company with ESV's older fleet of drilling rigs as well as its $5.2B in long-term debt.
    • RDC stands by the deal, which the company says "will create a uniquely positioned offshore drilling company with capabilities across all water depths, a significant fleet size, a broad geographic presence and a diverse customer base."

  • CFRX

    ContraFect down 37% on mid-stage exebacase data

    • Thinly traded nano cap ContraFect (CFRX -36.6%) is down on almost a 5x surge in volume following its announcement of Phase 2 data on exebacase (CF-301) for the treatment Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) bacteremia including endocarditis.
    • Treatment with exebacase, a recombinant form of an enzyme called lysin, added to standard-of-care antibiotics resulted in a clinically meaningful improvement in response rate at day 14 compared to antibiotics alone, but the separation appeared to fall short of statistical significance. Specifically, the response rate in the exebacase cohort was 70.4% versus 60.0% for antibiotics alone.
    • The company says exebacase produced statistically significant treatment effects in methicillin-resistant S. aureus patients and in those with bacteremia alone.
    • On the safety front, the rate of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) was 88.9% for exebacase compared to 85.1% for antibiotics alone. The rates of serious TEAEs were 47.2% and 51.1%, respectively.
    • Exebacase acts by targeting a certain area of the cell wall that is essential to the bacterium, making it less likely to develop resistance.
    • A Phase 3 trial is next up.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:27 AM | 72 Comments

    • That's notable since it's higher than the market capitalization of the parent company -- currently at €28.3B.

  • GE

    Analysts skeptical of potential GE-Apollo jet leasing deal

    • General Electric (GE +2.6%) gains in early trading following a report late Friday that Apollo Global is considering a bid for the company's jet leasing unit, but Wall Street analysts are skeptical of the actual size of a potential deal and its impact on GE's turnaround.
    • The jet leasing unit could be valued at as much as $40B, according to the report, but J.P. Morgan's Stephen Tusa says the unit could be worth closer to $30B and is unlikely to be the "silver bullet" that some investors might be expecting.
    • "We remain skeptical on the company’s ability to harvest enough value out of its assets to reduce liabilities, both hard and soft," Tusa writes.
    • Barclays' Julian Mitchell says while such a deal could reduce some of the existential risks faced by the company, a lasting impact on the equity value would require more clarity on the liabilities at GE Capital; "otherwise, the 'narrative' will remain impaired - i.e. 'good news is really bad news,' in that GE has to sell assets because of a looming major cash claim at [GE] Capital."
    • Gordon Haskett's John Inch says "while a potential GECAS transaction could be worth $40B, this would only match the book value of GECAS reported assets of just over $40B. Consequently, it is not clear what debt would be assigned to this transaction and what proceeds would be realized."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:46 AM | 47 Comments

    • The iShares Dow Jones US Home Construction ETF (BATS:ITB) rises after KeyBanc analyst Kenneth Zener writes that homebuilders and building products should gain due to a more optimistic macro sentiment, Bloomberg First Word reports.
    • He upgrades Lennar (LEN +3.1%), PulteGroup (PHM +3.8%), Masco(MAS +2%), and Gibraltar Industries (ROCK +3.7%) to overweight from sector-weight.
    • Sees H1 similar to previous trading cycles when builders rose 28% over six months as Powell's dovish commentary and Fed monetary policy should improve sentiment.

    • In the same vein, lower mortgage rates--their lowest in about eight months--may boost the housing market after a rough patch, the Wall Street Journal reports.
    • “I think there is latent demand on the sidelines given where rates are today,” said Sam Khater, Freddie Mac’s chief economist. “The problem is that volatility is the obstacle.”
    • Previously: Homebuilders stocks ready to ring out the year (Dec. 28, 2018)
